stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on Course 14, a craft-themed snow level. The main activities included designing and implementing a temporary bridge made of matchboxes, creating and debugging a crumpled paper snowball enemy, and developing a custom paper snowflake particle effect. He also discussed his game design philosophy, particularly his new Yoshi Coin system that replaces 100-coin stars.

development_findings.summary: The game features a dual-collectible system: Red Coins are localized to small challenge areas, while new Yoshi Coins are hidden throughout levels and reward non-obvious exploration and interactions.
development_findings.quote: Red coins in this game are always contained to one area because otherwise red coins suck... and the yoshi coins you get them for really rare special interactions.

development_findings.summary: The 7th star mission in each level is a treasure hunt for the remaining Yoshi Coins, aided by a proximity-based radar to make finding them less tedious.
development_findings.quote: Once you have the first six stars you get the seventh star which is just find the egg coins and find the egg coins has this radar here visible... that changes depending on how close you are to the egg coin.

development_findings.summary: The crayon, used to draw a star in the current level, is planned as a recurring mechanic. It will be used later to color in a map, revealing a hidden path.
development_findings.quote: The crayon mechanic wonâ€™t just be a one-off because right here there is a bit pipe and you will not see this when you fly actually. So what I was planning here is that there is like a map here and you can color the map and when you color the map a path appears.

development_findings.summary: The team brainstormed a temporary bridge mechanism, iterating from a simple cardboard plank to an unrolling bridge, before settling on a community-suggested idea of two matchboxes sliding out from either side.
After brainstorming names for the matchbox bridge, Kaze decided to use two different community-suggested brand names, 'Game & Match' and 'Lethal Lava Logs', on opposite sides of the gap.
development_findings.quote: We went from zero good ones to two good ones... I think they're both great and we should just use both. If you have two great ideas, why not use both?

development_findings.summary: Kaze implemented a paper snowflake environmental effect by adapting the code from an existing leaf effect, creating a new texture, and defining a spawn area.
Kaze was dissatisfied with the initial 'cotton ball' design for the snowballs and the way they were lit, prompting a redesign into a 'crumpled paper' ball.
development_findings.quote: This looks terrible and something about the lighting just looks very off too.

development_findings.summary: Kaze ended the stream still needing to design a proper launcher for the paper snowballs, as he found their current implementation of just appearing in the air to be visually jarring.
development_findings.quote: The snowball spawning there looks really bad. No, we need to do something about the snowball. We can't have this. It needs to come out of something.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has completely removed 100-coin stars from the game to eliminate the frustrating gameplay loop of avoiding stars to preserve a coin count.
context_findings.quote: I tried to get a star and then I have like 50 coins I'm like oh I might as well get the 100 coins star now and then I walk into a star and I'm like well I can't collect the star because I only have 50 coins I would lose all my coins and that just feels like shit.

context_findings.summary: Kaze revealed he received a DMCA from Nintendo's lawyers in 2019 for a previous project and responded crudely, facing no repercussions. He theorizes they may have decided he was 'mentally unstable' and not worth pursuing.
context_findings.quote: In 2019 I received a legit DMCA from a lawyer that Nintendo hired... And I responded to the email with just suck my cock, but in cock do I replaced with a zero so that wouldn't be filtered out. And nothing happened.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has decided to use the Godot engine for future original game development projects, citing its faster iteration speed and better performance for non-AAA games compared to Unreal Engine.
context_findings.quote: I've decided that if I'm gonna make my own game, we are probably using Godot. I talked to Godot left today to ask about how it compares to Unreal Engine 5... I think it's gonna be a lot more viable for development than Unreal Engine, because Unreal Engine is so goddamn slow.

context_findings.summary: Kaze disagrees with the development philosophy of avoiding high-quality placeholders, arguing that they are necessary to convey ideas to the team and verify functionality.
context_findings.quote: You should never build an asset that is a placeholder that looks like it could be final. And I think that's like a really stupid thing to say.

context_findings.summary: Kaze criticized the level design of 3D Sonic games, believing they deliberately obstruct the camera and player's view, which he considers a major design flaw.
context_findings.quote: For some reason the designers of sonic think or seem to think that not being able to see the level in front of you makes it better. It is a deliberate decision and that's crazy.

context_findings.summary: Zeina (Kaze's wife) and their baby daughter Reina made a brief appearance on the stream.
Kaze is skeptical about the upcoming Analogue 3D console, theorizing that the company's failure to send him a review unit, despite his prominence, suggests potential issues with the final product.
context_findings.quote: I'm thinking the only reason they would not send me a review copy is because something's wrong with it right?

biobak.summary: Kaze asked for Biobak's opinion on a new styrofoam model, indicating he values his input on visual elements.
Biobak is credited with having reworked some models to fix Z-fighting issues.
Biobak offered to pre-render a texture of matches for the inside of the matchbox bridge, solving a modeling problem for Kaze.
biobak.quote: OK, well, if you pre-render them, then I guess what I'm doing here is fine for now.

biobak.summary: Kaze expressed confidence that the placeholder crumpled paper snowball model will look correct after Biobak creates the final asset.
biobak.quote: It might not look like a crumpled piece of paper yet to you, but as soon as Biobak has had it, I'm sure it will look like exactly that.

zeina.summary: Kaze plans to ask Zeina to create the final, polished textures for the 'Game & Match' and 'Lethal Lava Logs' matchboxes.
zeina.quote: Surely this conveys the idea and Zeina can make a decent one.

zeina.summary: Zeina appeared on stream with their baby, Reina, and brought Kaze birthday cake.

key_stories.title: The Matchbox Bridge Design
key_stories.summary: To create a temporary bridge, Kaze and his community iterated through several ideas. They rejected an overly complex concept before settling on a chat-suggested matchbox design, which Kaze implemented with placeholder art, planning for Zeina to create the final version.
key_stories.challenge: The game's temporary bridge needed a design that was visually interesting, mechanically clear, and fit the level's craft theme.
key_stories.process: Kaze first considered a simple cardboard plank. He then thought of a more complex unrolling bridge but rejected it because the player would be too far away to appreciate the animation. After soliciting ideas from his chat, he embraced the matchbox concept, brainstormed pun-based brand names ('Game & Match', 'Lethal Lava Logs'), and implemented the functional bridge using modified existing code.
key_stories.outcome: The team settled on a design where two large matchboxes slide out from opposite platforms to form a bridge, a concept suggested by the stream's chat. Kaze created placeholder assets and tasked Zeina with creating the final textures.
key_stories.key_quote: We could spend hours programming that cool effect, but like, no one would get to see it.

key_stories.title: Redesigning the Coin and Star System
key_stories.summary: Kaze redesigned Mario 64's entire collectible system to better reward exploration and remove frustration. He eliminated 100-coin stars, localized red coin challenges, and added a new 'Yoshi Coin' collectible with its own radar-assisted mission to encourage players to find every secret.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze felt the original Mario 64's collectible system, particularly 100-coin stars and red coins, was often frustrating or boring and didn't adequately reward deep exploration.
key_stories.process: Kaze identified the core problems: the frustration of losing a high coin count to an accidental star grab and the tediousness of hunting for scattered red coins. He removed the 100-coin star entirely. He redesigned red coins to be self-contained challenges that don't kick the player out of the level. He then introduced Yoshi Coins as a separate reward for secrets, making them the objective of a final, radar-assisted mission in each level.
key_stories.outcome: A completely new system was created. 100-coin stars are gone. Red coins are now localized challenges. A new collectible, 'Yoshi Coins,' rewards obscure interactions and secrets, with a dedicated 7th mission and a radar to help players find them all.
key_stories.key_quote: With the system I wanted to solve the issue that there's no reason to explore like all the nooks and crannies in a level.

key_stories.title: Creating Craft-Themed Snow Effects
key_stories.summary: To fit the craft theme, Kaze designed and implemented new snow effects. He modeled a crumpled paper snowball and created a custom particle system for ambient snow using textures of paper snowflakes, successfully creating a cohesive and fitting atmosphere for the area.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze needed to create a convincing snowball and a snowflake particle effect that fit the level's 'arts and crafts' aesthetic using the N64's limited capabilities.
key_stories.process: Kaze first tried making a snowball from a white sphere with transparent fuzzy bits, but disliked the result. He then modeled a new snowball to look like crumpled paper. For the ambient snow, he copied and modified existing code for a leaf particle effect, created a new texture of a kindergarten-style paper snowflake, and implemented it as an environmental effect in a specific zone of the level.
key_stories.outcome: After a failed attempt at a 'cotton' ball, the snowball was redesigned as a crumpled paper ball. For the snow, Kaze created a custom particle effect using 2D textures of paper snowflakes, which he was very pleased with.
key_stories.key_quote: This looks extremely fitting to me. What do you think? You like it?

open_questions.topic: Future Original Game Development with Godot
open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned he has decided to use the Godot engine for future original games after speaking with a 'Godot dev'. He cited faster iteration and better suitability for smaller-scale games as key reasons.
questions: You mentioned talking to a Godot developer. Who was that and what were the key insights from that conversation that sold you on the engine?
What kind of original game do you envision making with Godot? Has working on this project influenced the genre or style you'd like to pursue?
How does the thought of starting a new project from scratch in Godot, without the SM64 base, feel to you? Is it exciting, daunting, or both?

open_questions.context: Kaze frequently mentions tasks for Biobak (reworking models, creating textures) and Zeina (creating the matchbox texture). The handoff seems informal.
questions: Can you walk me through the typical workflow when you need an asset from Biobak or Zeina?
How much creative freedom do they have? Do you provide detailed specifications, or is it more of a collaborative discussion?
How do you handle creative disagreements or feedback within the team? Can you give an example?

open_questions.topic: Relationship with Nintendo and Legal Risks
open_questions.context: Kaze told a story about receiving a DMCA from Nintendo's lawyers in 2019 for a past project and giving a defiant response with no consequences.
questions: You told the story about the 2019 DMCA. Looking back, what was going through your head when you sent that response?
Does the ever-present, though apparently dormant, legal threat from Nintendo affect your design decisions or how you approach this project?
How does the community's perception of you as a 'rebel' against Nintendo align with your own view of yourself and your work?

open_questions.context: Kaze ended the stream still unsatisfied with the snowball launcher, rejecting the idea of them just appearing from the sky but not having a clear solution.
questions: At the end of the stream, you were stuck on the snowball launcher design. What's your process for solving a creative block like that? Do you step away, brainstorm with the team, or just keep trying things?
Have you since figured out a design for the snowball launcher? Can you describe it?
How do you decide when a small detail like a snowball launcher is 'good enough' versus when it needs more work to feel right?

open_questions.context: Kaze briefly mentioned a 'vimstaller takedown' and a disagreement with someone named 'Vim' over whether the takedowns were legitimate, but provided no further details.
questions: You briefly mentioned something about a 'vimstaller takedown'. Could you explain what that situation was about?
Who is Vim and what was the nature of your disagreement about the legitimacy of the takedowns?
How do these kinds of community or external platform issues impact the development and morale of the project?
